101501.comment:
As an Ontario who's family is based in Richmond Hill, I made the choice to move to Downtown Toronto originally for school, and it was the best decision I have made because I get to live city life; walking and biking around town gives a freedom that driving does not match. I actually got into cycling because of the newly added bike lanes and how it made cycling so much safer for me and my friends. I've also driven in downtown toronto before regularly, and was always afraid of hitting cyclists because were sharing the lane. Bike lanes are an elegant solution that made driving downtown less stressful, and it makes bikers safer too.
Also ever since I picked up biking in town (mind you, I only committed to biking after the bikelane additions), I have been able to support businesses outside of core downtown like roncesvalles and east toronto, which would not have been feasible on foot alone, or inaccessible due to poor street car coverage. Bike infrastructure and biking helps toronto build a more resilient local business network!

101502.comment:
I’m astonished at how stupid this proposal is. Every single evidence-based study shows that when you increase transit and bicycle options, that traffic is reduced. It’s not rocket science, cars take up way more space per person and require more space between vehicles than bikes or buses do. I myself only started biking to work when the Bloor street separated lanes were installed, removing a car from the road.
Next- at a time when climate change is becoming increasingly real and obvious, to institute a policy that deters bicycling and encourages driving (while increasing traffic and therefore making pollution worse) is irresponsible and generationally-reckless.
Third- do you not understand that cyclists will die because of this? Human beings with families will die because of this decision. The difference in momentum between a cyclist and a car/truck is huge, and the car drivers do not respect that at all.
Fourth! My god please fund the healthcare system or transit or schools or something useful instead of wasting money and time to undo successful bicycle lanes that were put in by municipalities… as ironic as the statement is, STAY IN YOUR LANE.

101503.comment:
This is a terrible plan. There is no evidence that this change will improve gridlock. Improving gridlock is an unsupprted claim that will move Ontario back on the climate change mitigation front
Cycling is a healthy and environmental alternative that should receive more support if we are to achieve reduce CO2 emissions, in order to mitigate the increasing weather and health consequenses of our over-reliance on fossil fuels.
Please abandone this unhealthy and damaging Bill.

101505.comment:
This is a waste of time and money and a provincial overreach on something Torontonians have already voted for.
Doug Ford is using the province as his personal fiefdom and the lanes that were removed were already blocked by parking on Bloor st west.
The businesses that are complaining are upset about not having parking - not getting people moving in Toronto.
This whole bill is a sham and all documents related to this should be made part of a freedom of information access request because this smells of as much corruption as the Green Belt scandal already.
Our transit system is woefully inadequate to take on all of the additional riders if the bike lanes are not expanded/ removed.
Toronto voted for Olivia Chow for Mayor of Toronto and not Doug Ford or any of the candidates he supported that were against the new bloor st bike lanes. Respect the will of the electorate that live in Toronto.

101507.comment:
Bike lanes are backing up traffic all over, and are mostly unused for the majority of the day, and empty even more during inclement weather or the winter.
Roads were initially designed to handle the expected traffic flows. With our ever-growing population, the removal of traffic lanes in place of bike lanes only seems to make problems worse everywhere they are implemented.
I fully agree with this decision, and hope that the vocal minority of cyclists don't override the millions of motorists who have to deal with the gridlock traffic these bike lanes contribute to.

101511.comment: We all agree that humanity is facing a global climate crisis.Transportation is know to contribute an outsized role in the creation of carbon and other toxic emissions. Our government policies should encourage and make it easier for people to use public transportation and other forms of clean transportation more and incentivize people to rely on automobile use less. These policies do the opposite.  Canadians must do their part to alleviate this crisis, as must Ontarians. This will help to create a cleaner safer environment for future Ontarians to live in.

101512.comment: What you're proposing is illegal.  In Ontario bike lanes are not just for bikes, they're accessible lanes for disabled people.  You cannot rip out accessible infrastructure in Ontario and not replace it with something better.  As a disabled person that needs help walking and also have epilepsy I use a bike to go short trips (15km) or the day after I've had a seizure and not feeling well enough to drive.  Take away accessible lanes what other choice do I have but to drive when I feel drunk as a skunk after a seizure.

101513.comment:
The province should be making policies that maximize road space use for people, not for cars.
That means some streets, cars should dominate. But other streets, such as main shopping areas, pedestrians should dominate.
Bike lanes should be encouraged on all arterial roads in order to reduce congestion, since over 50% of street traffic are people traveling the distance of less than a 15m bike ride.
Bus-only lanes should also be encouraged on all arterial roads since buses move far more people than cars do.
Encouraging bus and bike use will reduce global environmental impacts as both modes use far fewer resources than both gas and electric cars.

101516.comment:
Bike lanes are necessary, especially on busy streets like the ones that this proposal looks to ban. Vulnerable road users Deserve and need safe lanes of travel to protect them against a 4000+ pound obstacle.
There are many citizens in this province who cannot or choose to not drive, especially in busy cities. it’s incumbent upon the premier and his government to put the safety of his citizens at the forefront over his desire to move vehicles swiftly.
There are ample studies that demonstrate that additional lanes of travel do NOT improve the flow of traffic. Over and above the scientific research that supports this one simply needs to look at the 401 and other massive highways throughout the world that continue to be bogged down through induced travel
It’s time that the premier puts the safety of the people he is supposed to be leading first

101518.comment:
This Bill is just silly. The kindest thing I can say about the notion that bike lanes cause congestion is this, from H. L. Mencken: “[T]here is always a well-known solution to every human problem—neat, plausible, and wrong.”
This Bill is clearly not meant to actually address congestion; it’s entirely political.
Follow the evidence of the studies instead. Cycle Toronto can provide them to you.

101519.comment: Installing bike lanes while removing lanes for vehicular traffic rarely makes sense. I am a supporter of bike lanes, especially safe and separated lanes where possible but reducing lanes of vehicular traffic in growing municipalities is not the answer. Forward thinking and planning is needed and investment in all forms of transportation is needed. The cost of installing bike lanes while removing vehicular lanes is not cost effective either.

101521.comment:
Please please please do not do this.
Bike lanes save lives.
Bike lanes help get people out of cars and reduce congestion.
Bike lanes make our roads less dangerous and more pleasant for everyone, drivers, cyclists, and pedestrians alike.
Bike lanes should be decided on by local decision makers at the municipal level, who understand their communities’ needs.
I cycle with my young children in Toronto. Bike lanes keep us safe.
Please do not put our lives at risk by throwing up administrative roadblocks to the construction of new bike lanes.

101523.comment: Please do not pass this misguided legislation. Bike lanes do not increase congestion, the opposite is often true, plus they improve road safety for ALL users, including drivers. They also decrease air pollution and improve fitness, thus have improved health outcomes, and lower healthcare costs, and make our cities quieter with a better quality of life for everyone. Please reconsider this legislation and instead introduce rational measures to INCREASE the number of bike lanes, properly fund mass transit, and get trucks off the 401 and into the 407.

101524.comment:
Saving 1 to 3 minutes is a waste of the government time and energy especially when these changes are going to put peoples lives at risk. “We saved you 1 minutes on your commute but since doing that 3 cyclist  have died along the route, it’s a small price to pay to save Ontarian time” says the conservative government in 2025.
Put your energy to use by address health care, the cost of living or access to housing

101525.comment: We need more bike lanes, not less!  Obviously a well used bike lane can move more commuters than a car lane.  Bike lanes need to be completely separate from the road for safety of all.  Paint on the road is not acceptable.  More bike lanes and better public transit is the way to reduce congestion on roads.
